awd_titl_txt: Submesoscale instabilities in the ocean bottom boundary layer: A new pathway for energy dissipation
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the long standing questions in physical oceanography is how the energy input to the ocean circulation is eventually dissipated, a problem with far-reaching implications for both our basic understanding of ocean circulation and for developing accurate ocean models. Recently it has been suggested that instabilities in the bottom layer and topographic wakes provide an important source of turbulent mixing, however the dynamics and energetics of these instabilities remain largely unexplored. At relatively small scales, where the rotation of the Earth is no longer the dominant factor, called submesoscales, instabilities in the ocean bottom layer modify the extraction, and dissipation of energy from the flow, and hence may alter classic conceptions of bottom turbulence. This research will use theory and idealized high-resolution numerical models to determine how submesoscale instabilities near the bottom, over and downstream of topography, modify turbulent mixing. These instabilities are believed to be common feature near the bottom, but are poorly understood in this setting relative to the surface layers. Likewise, these processes are currently absent in most large-scale ocean models, underscoring the need to develop a quantitative understanding of their impact and dependence on controlling parameters. This understanding is central to problems such as how dense water is brought to the surface in the abyssal overturning circulation, and the exchange of nutrients and other biogeochemical tracers between the bottom and interior layers. Results of this work will improve our understanding, and eventual parameterization, of dynamics along topography, and in particular how these boundary layer processes modify the larger-scale ocean circulation and energetics. This project will also enable the training of a postdoctoral researcher, and support the establishment of the initial research group of a junior faculty member.

Preliminary results suggest that submesoscale instabilities in the bottom boundary layer (BBL) open a new pathway for dissipating kinetic energy, and further modify the turbulent mixing of buoyancy near topography, believed to be a key aspect of how dense water is brought back to the surface in the abyssal overturning circulation. These results suggest that classic conceptions of how flow-topography interaction generates turbulence are incomplete, and the role of submesoscale instabilities needs to be considered. This project will investigate the energetics of baroclinic, symmetric, and centrifugal instabilities generated by flow along topography. Large-Eddy Simulation (LES) will be used to examine how these instabilities modify the partitioning and flux of energy between eddy and mean kinetic and potential energy terms, and the irreversible dissipation of kinetic energy and mixing of buoyancy. Reynolds-averaged simulations with variable topography will also be used, in conjunction with the LES, to determine how the upstream BBL evolution influences the energetics of topographic wakes. This work will provide a more complete description of the physical processes, and parameter dependencies, which determine how submesoscale instabilities affect the energetics of the ocean circulation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ocean currents that encounter topography can generate turbulent wakes, not unlike those that can sometimes be seen in the patterns of clouds in the atmosphere downwind of a steep mountain peak. Recent work has suggested that these interactions may generate a significant amount of turbulence, which could be important both for the energetics of the general ocean circulation, as well as for the mixing that occurs in both coastal and abyssal settings---a key process determining the nature of the ocean overturning circulation. The physics of these small-scale circulation features in the ocean are however not completely understood, in part because they tend to occupy a range of spatial scales (approximately 100 m to 10 km) which do not fall neatly into prior theories of ocean circulation. Despite this, work on similar scale processes in the surface ocean suggest a variety of possibilities for their mediating turbulent mixing that have not yet been fully explored.

This project explored the dynamics of flow interacting with bottom topography (including simple sloping 'coastlines' and more complex headland setups), as well as the detailed physical processes responsible for the mixing they generate. We developed theory to understand these processes, and utilized very high-resolution numerical modeling approaches that can resolve both the intermediate scales of the flow (1 km scales), as well as a portion of the turbulent motions (1 m scales). These simulations required the development of several new advances in a commonly utilized open-source simulation software to support our research needs. These improvements, as well as software for the analysis of simulation results, were made publicly available and have now been utilized by several other research groups.

The first goal of the project was to determine the physical mechanisms through which a certain class of hydrodynamic instabilities, believed common in wakes behind topography, can generate small-scale turbulent motion. Through analysis of numerical simulations we were able to show that instabilities create conditions amenable to the generation of even smaller-scale motions, leading to the onset of turbulent mixing. The strength of the mixing that results was then interpreted using prior results on stratified turbulence---developed in much more idealized settings than we considered---to find relationships between variables that can be used to predict the partitioning of turbulent energy loss between mixing and dissipation. We next turned to the development of more complex simulation configurations that included topographic features such as seamounts and headlands. Here we examined how the strength of the turbulent mixing downstream of these features was set by the intermediate scale processes (1 km scale) generated as the flow initially encountered the bottom. Our results suggest that while there are qualitative similarities between these features and similar processes studied at the surface, there are also quantitative differences in their energetics. This finding is important for interpreting observations, and for constraining the total mixing these topographic wakes contribute throughout the world's oceans.

Several other related topics were also explored. This included an investigation using a high-resolution realistic model of the Atlantic Ocean to determine how the near-bottom structure of currents (often not resolved in global ocean models) change the amount of energy removed by the bottom drag. We found that a reduction of near-bottom currents, not accounted for in prior analyses, implied an approximately 50% reduction of the total energy loss from the ocean circulation, leaving a gap in the total energy budget that may be partially filled by the sort of mixing processes described above. We also investigated how internal waves (which exist through a combination of forces from planetary rotation and the vertical layering of density in the ocean) generate mixing by breaking on steep underwater topography---not unlike waves breaking on a beach. Numerical simulations showed that the amount of mixing these waves generate, and the exchange between the ocean bottom and the ocean interior, can be understood through a parameter that is set by the wave strength and how rapidly the density changes in the vertical. This finding will be useful in interpreting observations and understanding how mixing at the boundary is ultimately communicated into the interior (including in properties such as heat, salinity, nutrients, and sediment).

Finally, this project supported the postdoctoral work of an early career researcher, and a PhD student, who were both trained on ocean physics and numerical simulation techniques. Several outreach lectures were also given on ocean physics, including virtual visits to K-12 classrooms, and through a professional tutorial on simulation methods at the Ocean Sciences Meeting 2022.
